questions.neutral: Heard the streets are tense again?

hobby.message: Urban exploration ever get boring for you?
Freestyle FPV... your kind of silence, right?
Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Plenty of unrest. People want answers now, not slogans.
Hard to focus on my collection work these days.
Tracking down banned books isn’t as simple with so many eyes open.
All this chaos, even the old volumes feel exposed.
It’s noisy out there, everyone picking through scraps of truth.
My collecting hobby—political texts, you know—got riskier this week.
Authorities are watching for anything, especially what’s not supposed to exist.
Tried to trade for a memoir, but shops are empty now.
People are snapping up every forbidden pamphlet they can find.
Tension, yes. Makes my collecting a little more… strategic lately.
I track down banned literature—old speeches, underground texts.
Since those BCI leaks, contraband is everywhere, hard to tell what's rare.
Last time I went out, the shelves were stripped bare by scavengers.
Even kids pass around pamphlets openly, no more secrecy needed.
Strange twist for a hobby that once thrived on silence.
Tense, and for someone who restores banned books, that’s an odd turn.
I’ve spent years hunting first editions of political works.
Before last week, every find felt like a secret coup.
After the billboard leaks, everyone’s trading banned literature in the open.
My favorite memoir disappeared from its hideout in the chaos.
Feels like the city’s reading what it never dared touch.
Sometimes I wonder if the chase meant more than the books themselves.
Heard it, felt it. I collect and restore banned political texts—whole shelves at home.
Spent decades memorizing forbidden manifestos, speeches councils erased.
Years ago, I could quote Kirsanov’s Proclamation by heart—carefully, only in trusted company.
Used to trade drafts for rare memoirs; last week chaos swept them all away.
When BCI leaks hit, shops were emptied overnight; young and old swapped underground texts in plain sight.
For once, I watched others recite lines I guarded for years.
My collection’s less secret now, but also less necessary.
Odd how a city’s upheaval can make an outlaw’s hobby ordinary.
hobby_answer: Yes. Still keeping me up.
Finding anything old is harder since those logs went public.
Shops got raided for pamphlets—now they're all gone.
Everyone thinks they’re an expert overnight.
Collectors like me need to keep quiet now.
Yes, political literature. Mostly what's left of it.
Used to trade with Anton for old manifestos.
Last week, the shop got hit—logs everywhere, books vanished.
Feels like everyone's trading propaganda on the street.
Hard to know who’s reading out of curiosity, who’s looking to report you.
Yes, still at it. Always another banned memoir to track down.
These days, blacklisted books aren’t rare, just lost.
After the BCI leak, pamphlets passed openly—lost all value as contraband.
Anton’s shelves are empty. Kids took everything.
Truth’s on the walls now—no one bothers to trade privately.
Almost poetic, but it kills the chase for me.
Strange seeing a secret hobby become communal property overnight.
Yeah, it keeps me up. Trading for old tracts was half the fun.
I’ve memorized whole manifestos. Used to swap books with Anton weekly.
Now, since the leaks, blacklists are everywhere—everyone wants fragments for their own walls.
His shop’s gutted. Pamphlets are common as cigarettes.
City feels like it’s running on cheap nostalgia and rumor.
The thrill is gone when everyone recites the same forbidden lines.
Missing the quiet puzzle of it—actual scarcity, not noisy abundance.
Feels like the old order’s been replaced by open chaos.
Always. Banned literature’s more home than hobby for me.
As a kid, I’d copy pamphlets by candlelight, hide them in wall cracks.
Old Anton was a lifeline for rare texts—until the BCI logs flooded the streets.
One week ago, I saw a teenage protester recite my favorite passage—one I never shared out loud.
All my careful curation erased by panic and mass copying.
My old codes, my chase—it’s public property now.
Suddenly the city speaks in illegal words, and no one’s afraid.
Half my identity is obsolete, replaced by mob copies and murals.
Feels lonelier now, watching everyone claim pieces I spent decades tracking.
